segments.text: Well, if you were to kind of start... Well, just to continue, you saw them going to school every day in their little uniforms and that.
So there was a... And I don't think it was just upper class.
I think everyone had an opportunity to be educated.
I just didn't see...
I saw very few what you may call street urchins roaming around.
Oh, there weren't?
No, there weren't.
You know, there weren't any gangs or anything like that, I didn't see.
Now, it so happened that the procurement agency was located in the prostitution district.
In your agency?
That's where it was.
It was right down on Plantation Road.
Is that what you call it?
That's right.
So, there was that going on there, but...
But as I say, the Vietnamese, and just like the Thais, had great respect for youth, and the parents loved their children.
Very touching.
Not very touching, but very admirable.
You said even you felt like all classes went to school.
Was there a great class society?
I mean, can you tell a big distinction?
I think there was a class.
It was more by education than by money.
Education probably made the distinction, you know, than money.
Was there a lot of money?
Didn't you have a lot of money?
I really couldn't tell, but I don't think...
I didn't see poverty there.
Let's put it that way.
I did not see poverty.
I didn't see poverty in Thailand either.
And I didn't see it, now we don't know, I don't know whether it was, hey, the wartime economy in Saigon meant there was a lot of money around because everybody could get a job.
But I would sort of suspect that was it.
There was a lot of money around and everybody could get a job.
Do you think this was because of the contract we were having that a certain ratio had to be Vietnamese?
I don't know whether that was it, but they're probably very industrious people, and even without that, they were getting a spillover, maybe not such a direct spillover.
When we say 20% to Vietnamese, that meant 20% of our in-country expenditures were going directly to the Vietnamese.
But even before that, I think it would have probably reached the Vietnamese, but maybe through one or two middlemen, you know?
Right.
But I think we were making sure that more got down to the Vietnamese.
That was, as I said, both through the contractors and requiring contractors to employ Vietnamese.
And I didn't see anything which would be indicative of graft or corruption.
Do you have any certain personal relationship with the Vietnamese person?
No, it was just all business.
Although I got that vase up there from the young lady in the office.
But we all liked it so much that when I went to Hong Kong on a R&R, we bought her a typewriter from the office.
Because we felt that she could use this at home or maybe a little business or the rest of it.
So everybody in the office chipped in and we got her a typewriter, among other things.
Is she still over there now?
I would guess so.
I really lost touch.
In fact, I didn't maintain any touch with anybody.
I don't usually when I'm over there.
Right.

because it's profitless and I don't mean that from the monetary sense I mean that from the emotional sense it's profitless what we had in common is God I'm not there anymore and you're there so I don't maintain any relationship with people I've served with before very rare exception what we had in common was our service together that's over and I'm going on to new friends
And you're going on to new friends.
If we meet again, we'll be friends again, but... We're going on.
That's right.
Everybody goes forward.
Right.
Well, if you were going to sum up your experience in Vietnam, what would you say?
I would say it was entirely worth it.
I would say entirely worth it in every respect.
I like the experience.
I like the service.
I thought we were trying to do some good there.
I never felt a sense that we were being rejected by the Vietnamese people, that we were doing something unpopular.
And you might say, well, in Saigon, where everybody was under the thumb of the police, you think that is realistic.
But I was out in the country, too.
And people were either the ones that I had an opportunity to see were either for us or, at worst, indifferent.
But I saw we did a lot of good, I thought, with the economy.
And I only saw the best of motives towards the .. Only the best of motives.
And to say, hey, such a nice and wonderful and fine people, you're first certainly going to feel a certain remorse that something like this had to happen.
When you talked about the countrymen, the country people that you saw, do you feel like there was more indifference out there than there really was feelings?
Did a lot of people just live their own lives?
Well, they tried to.
They tried to.
But in some way or not, in some way they're certainly going to be involved.
But you're going to get...
people very well in the combat zones, in the fire zones, certainly couldn't be indifferent to it because they were threatened every day from either one side or the other.
Maybe not intentionally, but the threat was there when you drop that many explosives and you engage in that sort of violence, one no matter how innocent or how...
the desire to keep out of the way, you do become involved.
Just like even in Saigon, we were involved with the little terrorist activities and the rest of it.
You're always conscious of that.
Even in the hotel room or going to and from work, I always carried a pistol and carried it on my lap because...
You didn't know who was out there.
That's right, that's right, that's right, that's right.
And you always figured that if you were prepared, the person might go along and pick on somebody else.
So even though you were in Saigon, as well as I said, there was always that fear.
Well, always that vigilance.
Vigilance would be a word.
Oh, you never let that vigilance down.
You were always concerned.
At least I was.
I was always concerned, always aware that you figured that the more vigilant you were, the less of a target you would appear to be, less of an attractive target you would appear to be.
And everybody, everybody carried guns.
Everybody had guns.
And they treated them with respect.
Respect, I mean, it was.
It was just like you would, you yourself would carry your purse to school.
When you got up in the morning, you put on the gun.
Went to work.
You carried it, you loaded it, it was loaded, and you kept it in, on driving in the car, you kept it in your lap.
And so it was always, you never went out without it.
Never went out without it.
So I would say, hey, the Vietnamese people were concerned, and
There had to be, too, because I remember that they would run convoys through the city, and Vietnamese traffic is just like any other Oriental city.
So I got a great deal of traffic.
Now, these convoys, what they would do is they would get these five-ton trucks, and they would run through the city with their horns going, and they wouldn't stop.
They would jump one stop and maybe it would be about, and going about 40 miles an hour through the crowded streets.
40 miles an hour might not seem to you, but through crowded streets and a lot of intersections.
But you knew that you could hear those horns going, those air horns, maybe about a half a mile away.
And you knew you better get out of the way because they did not stop for lights.
They did not stop at anything.
In a five-ton truck, he would just run over you, and he wouldn't even feel it.
He'd just keep going.
Keep going.
So it was those kind of things that was always, I would imagine, caused the local populace to always be constantly reminded that something was going on.
Do you think after the UN was met in the Vietnam War,
Now, when we got involved with another country, would we be careful of getting involved?
Well, I think you can see that in Central America.
Everybody's concerned.
They've got it on their mind.
We don't want it to be another Vietnam.
This is only the beginning of involvement.
I see that on the television each night.
Nobody can say, hey, we shouldn't give aid to these people.
This is the beginning of another Vietnam.
Do you think that's a true statement, or do you think it's a statement to say, yeah?
Well, I don't know how, I don't really know how true it is.
The really thing is we have to, I think we have to probably decide for ourselves whether it's going to involve another Vietnam or not.
Is it necessary to become involved?
Apparently when we became involved in Vietnam, people thought it was necessary.
Maybe they didn't have the foresight to see that it would end in that manner.

But now that they have one experience, I think we will not be influenced by... Oh, yes, we probably will be influenced by Vietnam in that people will make the decision a lot more carefully, saying we will become involved even if it becomes a Vietnam or we won't become involved because it's not worth it.
Do you think that people that came home from Vietnam got to talk about it or was it hushed up?
I think they talked about it as much as they wanted to.
I think if you wanted to talk about Vietnam, you could.
I never had any problem with people saying, don't talk about it, or I talked with people who were over there.
We always talked about it.
people who've been over there, why did you do, how was it, what were your experiences?
So I didn't, I've never found any reticence by anybody to talk about it if they wanted to.
But people just, just over and done with it.
So you wouldn't take, you'd go again?
Oh, sure, sure, sure, sure, sure.
Well, maybe it's because I didn't have any unhappy experiences there, except, you know,
what ultimately happened to the people.
That's got to be unhappy.
That's got to be sad for us all.
But yes, the experience was just good.
It's like all military experience in the world, but just a question of degree.
Well, thank you for letting me in.
OK.
